Author: Alright#0419
Content: Yea we really need to concise explanation of what it is. To simplify(a lot) it's a platform for testing smart contracts. A coin dev wouldn't want their first iteration of their smart contract in their coin immediately as it might require many hard forks to get right. With STAKED, dev can launch a chain with their own contract, if there is a problem, they simply kill the chain, update the contract and start another

Author: Alright#0419
Content: STAKED is also the only way to have opt-in crypto condition contracts as opposed to compulsory consensus rules

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if a normal asset chain wants to add/update a contract, all nodes need to update

Author: Alright#0419
Content: with STAKED, not the case

Author: Alright#0419
Content: If you want to use a contract on STAKED, you just sync the chain it's on and transfer coins to it

Author: jorian#4555

Author: jorian#4555
Content: the reason for having notaries?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: We couldn't expect KMD notaries to deal with our constant updates

Author: Alright#0419
Content: tonnes of custom stuff as well

Author: jorian#4555
Content: yes but why would you want this second set of notaries? to notarize what exactly?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: They notarize STAKED chains directly to KMD

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Our notaries have the ability to watch an oracle for new chains, if publisher pushes a new chain to oracle, notaries sync it and start notarizing with 0 human intervention

Author: jorian#4555
Content: that's awesome

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Notaries will "subscribe" to publishers, set a minimum amount of STAKED they want to receive before notarizing the chain

Author: Alright#0419
Content: so you can become a publisher and have people come to you and say "hey, please add this chain"

Author: Alright#0419
Content: or add chains yourself

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you just need enough notaries to subscribe to your oracle
